SP.P: Only general insinuations, ingeniously cal∣culated, as she supposed, to damp the ardour of my pursuit, and which have but served to add another rivet to those chains that bind me eternally hers.

SP.SPEAKER: Weston.
SP.P: She is truly politic: Were women but sen∣sible what charms unite in a candid, generous and frank deportment, even their love of sway would teach them to renounce the wily arts of deception.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: Faith, I am glad to see thee, Charles: How is't, my boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Intolerable familiarity. [Aside.] When did you come to town, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: Two days since, Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Do you bring any news, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: News, old boy, what of news? Why thou lookest plaguy glum. I should hardly have run through fire and water to see thee, if I had prophesied such a reception; and I have, bona fide, laboured more to make myself visible in this apartment, than ever Alex∣ander the great did, in cleansing the Herculean stables.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Idiot. [Aside.] What has been the mat∣ter, Captain?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: The matter! Why one lady insisted that I should dine with her; a second, that I should take tea; and a third, that I should pass an hour tete-a-tete: But at Bloomville's I was absolutely arrested; my hat and cane purloined; and I concluded I was made a prisoner for the day.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: You have been at Major Bloomville's, then; How did you make your escape?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: A stratagem, Charles—a mere stratagem. Hector surprised and captivated Troy by stratagem. You are to know that I am an immense favourite with the ladies at Bloomville's; for the Major, he is one of your sober dogs; but the lady of the house might vie with the mother of the Scratehii, when she visited king Solomon to admire his wisdom; and the charming Eliza, for whom, by the way, I have conceived an insur∣mountable tendresse, is as beautiful as a vestal, and not even Penelope, when she stole her father's images, was a greater thief; for, with one glance of her bright eyes, she hath pilfered the stout heart of a soldier, who has had the honour to serve under the great WASH∣INGTON; who escaped from the savages with half a dozen wounds, upon the tremendous fourth of Novem∣ber, and who hath since been principally concerned in quelling the whisky insurrection.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Amazing!

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: Admitted into all WASHINGTON's coun∣cils—finger next to the thumb—nobody but Captain Flashet, Captain Flashet, at every turn.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Prodigious! I could kick the puppy.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Colonel Mellfort, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Desire the Colonel to walk in.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: Gentlemen, your most obedient—Mr. Maitland, good morning; agreeably to promise, I just call en passant.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: You do me honour, Sir; pray be seated.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: I have not a moment to tarry, Sir. My stay in town will be short; and, desirous to see as ma∣ny of your curiosities as time will permit, I have en∣gaged to meet some friends in the Mall, this morning, from whence we are to commence our tour of obser∣vation.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Will you permit me to accompany you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: Sir, it will give me singular pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Will it be convenient for you to join us, Mr. Weston?

SP.SPEAKER: Weston.
SP.P: Perfectly so, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: A sheer affront, by Jupiter! But, by the rules of Longinus, nothing is ill meant, until it is ill taken; and so I will after them to the Mall, heap coals of fire on their heads, and thus take an honourable revenge.

DIV2.STAGE: [Mr. Maitland in full dress; rings violently.]

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Here—set chairs—there, that will do.—You may go, boy.

DIV2.STAGE: [Maitland adjusting his cravat and periwig in the glass.]

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: What can this Madam Matronia possibly want with me? Her character stands very high in the world; but women are women. I have heard that she liked my house—liked my son—liked my fortune, my principles, and my way of life. Now, if she should chance to have taken a liking to my person too—he, he, he—there is no calculating the caprices of the sex; but fair and softly. I have had one wife—one good wife too—and on just and equal distribution, one good wife is as much as ought to fall to the lot of one man: To continue a bachelor is one extreme, repeated mar∣riages is another; a Medium is my hobby horse, and dearly do I love to canter thereon; therefore, and for this reason, among many others that might be urged, dear, good, faithful Gertrude, I will continue loving and constant to thy memory.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Madam Matronia, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Show her in.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P:
Now will I be as coy as a young maiden,
when she is first left alone with her future lord and master, after he has obtained the approbation of the old folks.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Madam, your most obe∣dient.

SP.SPEAKER: Matronia.
SP.P: Sir, I have taken the lib∣erty to call on you this morning on very particular business.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Madam, you do me a great deal of honour. Pray be seated.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Sir, you are very polite; but I really feel a little awkward.— [Hesitating confusedly, blushing, and looking down.] New to negociations which custom hath in some sort interdicted my sex, a degree of em∣barrassment may be compatible with the most upright intentions.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Madam, I am entirely at your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: You are very obliging, and I flatter myself, that, in this my native place, my character is so well established, that a person of Mr. Maitland's well known candour will not see the necessity of scruples; and, although the nature of my request may be allowed to excite your surprise, yet as my honour hath hitherto remained unimpeached, you will not think it a very improper one.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Lord! Lord! what shall I say to her? [A∣side.] As to that, Madam—as to improper, and all that, it is hardly possible to say any thing about it. Some things are proper, and some are improper—I am not fond of extremes—others are—and so we wrap it up, Madam. I prefer liberty; I have been married, Madam—you have not; every one to his fancy. I, for my part, am perfectly content as I am.

DIV2.STAGE: [Maitland appears embarrassed; takes out his snuff-box, and plays whimsically with the lid.]

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P:
Good heavens! what can he mean? [Aside.] Sir, I must confess you are a little ambiguous; but, to prevent every possibility of mistake, I will be very explicit. I have invested the whole of my property in
bank stock—I have immediate occasion for one thou∣sand pounds, for which I will give my note; there are some formalities attendant on drawing money out of our public repositories, which I am willing to spare myself; and, if you can conveniently furnish we with this sum on my engagement that it shall be returned to you in one month, the purpose, the whole purpose [bowing] of my visit here this morning, will be pleas∣ingly answered.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Is that all? [Aside.] Madam, I am hap∣py—I had thought—I, I, I, am extremely happy, upon my soul, and I will fetch you the bills immedi∣ately. Well, I am greatly relieved. [Aside.]

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Well, this is singular, upon my word; ha, ha, ha, truly ridiculous. It is beyond a doubt, that this good old gentleman supposed me a candidate for the vacant place in this elegant mansion! Surely it should teach me a lesson; for, if pursuits, far from being reprehensible, and a purpose that indisputably wears the garb of virtue, cannot shield from injurious suspicion, how are the vo∣taries of folly exposed to the multiplied shafts of cen∣sure! Unhappy sex! whose ways are environed with peril; surely we should not fail hourly to invoke the guardian care of attending angels.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Here, Madam, here they are—exactly one thousand pounds; and you have only to sign this bond, and the business is finished.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Sir, the facility with which you have complied with my wishes, and your confidence in my honour, hath made me eternal∣ly your debtor.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: O! it is a mere bagatelle; never mention it, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Assure yourself, Sir, that I shall be punctual; some affairs of great urgency have impelled the ap∣plication of this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: It matters not, Madam; I make no in∣quiries—life is always subject to vicissitudes! and, to say truth, I have myself been lately thrown from the equality of disposition that I am accustomed to pre∣serve.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Really! I trust no accident hath happened in your family, Mr. Maitland.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, an accident of the greatest possible magnitude!

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: May I ask of what nature, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: My son, Madam, my only son, hath thought proper to fall irretrievably (as he says) in love with one Eliza Clairville.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: And is this the accident which hath so dis∣turbed you?

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: It is, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Is it possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: What is there in it so strange?

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Excuse me, Sir, if I express my wonder at your regarding this event as a misfortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Why, ought I not to regard it as a misfor∣tune, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: I think not, Sir—Eliza Clairville possesses more dignity of sentiment than any young person I have met with; she is a high soul'd girl, and has more of mind than commonly falls to the lot of mortality.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: It may be so; but I hate all extremes; and I had rather she were less aspiring.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: I wish she would cease to play off her light airs on my boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Sir, a sense of obligation ought, perhaps, to seal my lips; but, thus urged, I must say you do Miss Clairville much wrong; and I take a par∣ticular pleasure in repeating that she is the most fault∣less young lady within my knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Pray, Madam, how long have you known her?

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P:
Years, Sir—ever since she has been in the country; the lady, under whose protection she left
France, yielded her reluctantly to my care; and, re∣garding her as a model of discretion, I bestowed her up∣on my niece, on her marriage with George Bloomville.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: And how long has my hopeful son been enlisted in her service?

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Your son, Sir, was early captivated by the charms of Miss Clairville; nor should you have want∣ed the fullest and most timely intelligence of this event, had there existed the smallest probability of a union of the parties.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: I do not understand you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Sir, I pledge my honour, my life, my repu∣tation, that you shall never be entitled to call Eliza Clairville daughter, but by your unbiassed and avowed choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Very well, very well; this looks well; the young woman may be prudent; and if she behaves properly, she will merit my thanks.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Sir, my visit has been unexpectedly prolong∣ed: I wish you a good morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: I will attend you to your carriage, Madam.

DIV2.HEAD: VIRTUE TRIUMPHANT, continued. ACT SECOND.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE—A beautiful Garden, adjoining to Major Bloomville's House.
[Eliza Clairville, seated in an alcove, pensively sings:]

LG.L: AH me! what ills encompass round,
How thick the shafts of sorrow fly;
Of hapless , how deep the wound,
How pangful the corroding sigh!
An angel, in discretion's form,
The orphan'd maiden should attend;
To shield her from the gathering storm,
With faithful vigils should descend.
Oh! if Eliza's plaints could woo
The seraph from the bending skies,
Then might her feeble steps pursue
That smooth shorn path which peace supplies.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: No, it will not be—music has not charms sufficient to remove the melancholy pressure by which I am borne down. Unhappy girl! orphan∣aged in my dawn of being—thrown on the com∣passion of strangers—rendered, by the malice of my fate, an outcast from that compassion—exiled in a foreign land—involved in a hopeless passion—every sentiment of my soul approving him, whom virtue im∣pels me to reject! Wretched, wretched Eliza! ill-fated maiden! it is only from the icy darts of death thou canst expect relief!

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Madam, forgive this intrusion; I sought you in the house; your servant informed me you were here; and having business of importance to myself, I so far presumed on your indulgence as to follow you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: The visits of my friends, Mr. Maitland, can never be unwelcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: How cutting is this indifference! [Aside.] Perhaps, Madam, I ought to esteem myself happy, that I am admitted in the number of your friends; and yet, Miss Clairville, to purchase a dearer title, had I worlds to bestow, I would think them well re∣linquished!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P:
It is matter of regret to me, Sir, that instead of that sentimental intercourse, which it would be one of my felicities to cultivate, you should thus snatch ev∣ery
opportunity of reference to a subject, which ought never to have been introduced.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Ought never to have been introduced, Madam! Can, then, the rational Eliza think so se∣verely of that tender connexion, which hath received the sanction of all ages, and which is the source of ev∣ery felicity?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: No, Sir; Eliza Clairville does not think se∣verely of wedded amity; she respects, as she ought, the sacred ties of mutual love; but when fate inter∣poses its insurmountable bars, it surely must be consid∣ered as the height of folly, to be thus unceasingly at odds with destiny.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Ah! Eliza, did you but know the dag∣gers which your words convey, you would exercise more lenity. Once more I solemnly protest, that, to call you mine, no sacrifices would be deemed too great! with you, each spot would seem a paradise! without you, life remains a barren wilderness.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Sir, this is too much; your looks too abso∣lutely border on frenzy! If you persist in what I can scarce forbear to term an ungenerous persecution, I must, however reluctantly, request Mrs. Bloomville to deny me to your visits.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Ah! Madam, you may spare that request. I have called on you this morning to make one last effort; the success of this effort I have already seen; and, with to-morrow's sun, I bid you, perhaps, an ev∣erlasting adieu!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: How, Cha—Mr. Maitland—What can you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Simply this, Madam. Traversing the Mall this morning with a friend, of whose worth, while in New-York, I had repeated proofs, we accidentally dis∣covered that, added to the ties of amity, we were also kindred of the melancholy mood. Allied by misfor∣tune, we have agreed to become companions in exile; and, with the coming day, I depart from those native haunts, which my Eliza—forgive the freedom of a de∣spairing youth—can alone teach me to value!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Are you serious, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Certainly, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Have you the approbation of your father?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: My father will suppose me on a tour of busi∣ness. [Eliza, much disordered, melts into tears.] Good Heaven! Miss Clairville, what mean these tears? Surely, the purple stream that warms me to existence, is not so precious in my estimation. Oh! could I flat∣ter myself, that tenderness for me impelled the kindly gush—But no—it is impossible—Eliza, in what have I offended?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Mr. Maitland, your unimpeached veracity forbids me to question your sincerity—You certainly leave town to-morrow?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Undoubtedly; unless I should be so super∣latively blest, as to be honoured by a countermand from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: In such a moment as this, then, virtue her∣self will permit a degree of relaxation. You have of∣ten, Mr. Maitland, accused me of insensibility: Alas! you little knew the heart you thus arraigned; it was cast in the mould of tenderness, and its dearest senti∣ments have ever been the offspring of friendship and of love.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: But these blest sentiments refused to sanc∣tion the vows of Maitland!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: I will be very explicit, Sir. Had I been addressed by a man, whom my heart and my judgment had approved, and who had been born the equal of my humble family and lowly fortunes, to a single moment's sus∣pense he should not have been condemned; my extended hand, accompanying my yielding heart, our mutual attachment should have received the sanction of the holy priest; and it would have become my study, to ameliorate the interest I had obtained in his bosom.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Charming, inimitable woman! I would have died to have originated an affection so divine!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P:
Ah! Charles, is it possible you have yet to learn, that you are indeed the friend of my choice—that my tenderest wishes are your's? Nor will I blush
to own, that if propriety and virtue would permit, this hand should be only your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.STAGE: [Seizing her hand, and bowing upon it.]
SP.P: Heavens and earth! What do I hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: You hear a truth, Sir, which, had not insur∣mountable obstacles have opposed our union, should long since have been familiar to your ear—You hear a truth, for which my breast should still have been a grave, had not the precipitancy of your departure extorted it from me: But the knowledge that we are to meet no more, hath produced, by way of justice to my feelings, a declaration, which sincerity hath a thousand times suggested. And now, Charles, may eternal blessings crown your virtues—receive my last adieu!

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: What means my angel?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: That, as you depart on the morrow, a mo∣ment like this may not again present.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: And think you, dear, enchanting girl, that, so unexpectedly attaining the summit of felicity, I will thus voluntarily relinquish my stand?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Surely, Charles Maitland will not de∣ceive me?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: My projected banishment was on the ago∣nizing presumption, that Eliza never could be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: And it is as true, as that her each pulsation beats for thee, that she never can be thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: You deal in paradoxes, my love!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: My meaning must surely be obvious: Eliza Clairville will never unite herself to a man, whose fam∣ily detests her.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Let us hope that my father may be pro∣pitiated.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: That hope is not the offspring of probabili∣ty; it may serve to illumine the pages of a novel, or produce a happy denoeument to the fifth act of a play; but as it consists not with reason, let us not indulge it. No, my friend, prosecute your intended plan, and ten∣der remembrance shall be dear to our bosoms! in dreams we will converse, and in future worlds we shall be happy! Once more, adieu!

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Distraction! a moment stop, if you would not reduce me to a state of desperation!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: What I can still urge to soothe your wounded spirit, I will not withhold; and, in the same moment that I declare, I never, but on equal terms, will plight my faith with your's, I pledge to you my veracity, that this heart shall never know a second lord—that this hand shall never be given but to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Heavenly condescension! Matchless good∣ness! I am in a delirium of joy!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Leave me, Charles; I entreat you to leave me; and remember, I expect the performance of your journey!

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: And shall we, then, meet no more?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: On this one condition—that, with to-mor∣row's sun, you accompany your friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Divine, yet severe arbitress, I obey—the mingling emotions of my bosom, it is not in language to express. May guardian seraphs hover round you!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.STAGE: [After standing a moment in an attitude of re∣flection.]
SP.P: I am not sure I have acted quite right—the trial was unexpected, and more than proportioned to my discretion: But even repentance cannot recal the past; and, having enough of present misery, I will cease to arraign, or to investigate.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE—An Apartment in Major Bloomville's House—Books and Papers promiscuously thrown about.

SP.SPEAKER: Major B.
SP.P: Madam, those mere bagatelles, on which the censorious world is pleased to comment so severely, would be placed by me, to the account of youth, a consciousness of superior beauty, and extreme inexpe∣rience, were I sure she regarded me with that decided preference, which a husband has a right to expect.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Bless me, nephew! you terrify me! Have you any doubts of her fidelity?

SP.SPEAKER: Major B.
SP.P: No, Madam, not absolutely. Augusta Bloomville has too much pride to submit to actual de∣basement; yet, give me leave to observe, that, bred in the school of honour, I have imbibed a soldier's delicacy, and I am ready to say, "Cesar's wife should not be suspected."

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: I have, indeed, grieved to find my niece so little domesticated, and so regardless of your interest; but I had flattered myself, that the innate rectitude of her mind had rendered her conduct, in other respects, irreproachable.

SP.SPEAKER: Major B.
SP.P: Far be it from me, Madam, to accuse my Augusta; and yet, to you, her more than parent, it may not be wrong to say, that I live in a state of mar∣ried solitude! that my Augusta, all charming as she is, constitutes to me, a source of agonized inquietude! Shop-hunting, visiting, cards, balls; these make up the routine of her life; while her husband can scarce obtain the smallest attention!

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Strange, strange degeneracy!!!

SP.SPEAKER: Major B.
SP.P: Every powder'd puppy has her smile—that coxcomical wretch—that Flashet, is at this mo∣ment gallanting her through the streets, and escort∣ing her to the new milliner's, Mrs. Lacewell's, where she will doubtless empty her pocket-book.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Have you made her acquainted with your late embarrassments?

SP.SPEAKER: Major B.
SP.P: I have not; for, notwithstanding her un∣kindness, I cannot, for my soul, bring myself to in∣flict on her a single moment's unnecessary pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Your indulgence merits a reward; and a thorough knowledge of the principles of my niece au∣thorizes me to say, that time will remove your dif∣ficulties.

SP.SPEAKER: Major B.
SP.P: Heaven grant it.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Amen. I have taken up for you, George, one thousand pounds, of which I think you said you stood in immediate need.

SP.SPEAKER: Major B.
SP.P: You surprise me, Madam! Surely, you have not withdrawn your interest from the stocks?

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: No, George, I have not—inquire no fur∣ther. Let it suffice, that I have deranged no plans, and that I have procured the money on common interest.

SP.SPEAKER: Major B.
SP.P: Ever since the moment which introduced me to the knowledge of Matronia, she hath continued uniformly and condescendingly kind, and my obliga∣tions are unreturnable.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: You estimate common actions too highly. Here are the bills; and if they may contribute to your convenience, my reward will be more than propor∣tioned to my merit!

SP.SPEAKER: Major B.
SP.P: They will do me incalculable service, Madam; and I will go this moment and adjust a busi∣ness, in which my commercial reputation is import∣antly involved.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: And I will await the return of my niece in her dressing-room.

SP.SPEAKER: Major B.
SP.P: Incomparable woman! If she succeeds in shaping the conduct of her niece after the model of her own exalted character, my happiness will be complete. Here, William—

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: Did you call, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Major B.
SP.P: Yes, William; take care of these books and papers; and, if I am inquired for at dinner, let your mistress know, I shall not return until the even∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: My mistress! um, um, um! she will hardly make the inquiry, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Deb.
SP.P: Here, you fellows, William, John, Thomas, Molly! Why, where the dickens are you all? You Sir, why do you loiter thus, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P:
I wonders who calls—so I does—one would think the house was on fire—I never was in such a place in all my born days—so many mistresses—
'fackins! I wishes I was at home, milking my cows again—so I does.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: Zookers! Molly, don't speak so loud; for if you do, Mrs. Deborah will hear you, as sure as eggs is bacon.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: And who cares if she does? [contemptuously.]

SP.SPEAKER: Deb.
SP.P: Why, what the plague are you muttering about, there? Did you expect to come into such a house as this, to sit on the cupboard's head? Only see now, what a litter is here! Do you not know, there are ladies calling every hour in the morning?—rap, rap, rap—no peace for the knocker. Here, you dain∣ty fingers, clear these message-boards, that we may have room for fresh cards; and you, William, do you pick up these books and papers, and see that the steps and street before the door are thoroughly swept and cleansed.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: Pray now, good Mistress Deborah, what is all this bustle about? Why need you put yourself in such a wicked passion?

SP.SPEAKER: Deb.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, saucy jackanapes. Do you not know, that there are strangers expected at din∣ner, and company in the afternoon? Stir your stumps, I say; stir your stumps, all of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: I'm resolv'd I gives Madam warning before to-morrow night—getting up by break of day in the morning, sitting up till midnight, cleaning here, and running there—one has not a moment's quiet—and I gets nothing by it after all, only four dirty shillings a week, while Mrs. Gadabout's Susan has a whole dol∣lar, only for dressing her mistress's false hair.

SP.SPEAKER: Deb.
SP.P: Let's have none of your sauce, Mrs. Minx. Marry come up! Do you not know, 'tis an honour to serve Mrs. Bloomville? But while I am spending my time to talk to you, my cakes and tarts will be burnt to cinder; so you had best mind your business, and get the room in order as soon as possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: I'll not stay here—so I won't.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: Pshaw, pshaw! good Molly, never mind it, never mind it. Why, I'll be hang'd now, if I don't think Mistress Deborah was born scolding; and what is bred in the bone will never come through the skin, as the saying is.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Why, William, it would provoke a minis∣ter—so it would.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: I tell you what, Molly, I have been thinking and thinking, and I do now really believe, as sure as we are born, Molly, that this Mistress Deborah of our's, is the Witch of Endor.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: That she is, Mr. William; and so, as every good Christian should, I hates all witches and witch∣goblins, as bad as I hates Old Nick.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: Ah! that's right, Molly, that's right—But we must make haste now, and do our work, or she, being a witch, will sartingly bewitch us, and haunt us into the bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Deb.
SP.P: Here you, Molly, William! Where the plague are you both?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Let me die if she ben't calling again. Well, I knows I'll quit this service before it be very long.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: I follows Molly—butter me if I don't.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE—Another Apartment in Mr. Bloomville's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: It is in vain I shift the scene! the settled gloom on my spirit knows no abatement!

DIV2.STAGE: [Enter Miss Dorinda Scornwell, sans ceremonie, and with a supercilious air.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: Is your lady visible to∣day, child?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Madam Bloomville is in her dressing-room, Miss Scornwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: Why, what's the matter, young woman? you look disturb'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Pardon me, Madam, I am perfectly tranquil.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: Well, girl, will you trip to your lady, and let her know, Miss Dorinda Scornwell has done her∣self the honour of calling on her this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: You shall be obeyed, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: Creature! she absolutely apes the grace and dignity of we people of fashion. I hate your dirt-sprung beings. If this Bloomville was a degree re∣moved from idiotism, she would long since have dis∣carded her, especially as I have so often remonstrated on this head.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: Madam, my mistress requests your company in her dressing-room.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: I attend her, William.

DIV2.STAGE: [Matronia and Mrs. Bloomville seated—Miss Dorinda Scornwell enters—both ladies rise and courtesy.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Dear Dorinda, I am monstrously happy to see you! I called at your lodgings en passant, in the course of a tour I have been making among the shops, and was mortified to death at not finding you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: You are a charming creature, it must be confessed: But it is a divine morning; and I have al∣ready looked in on a little hundred of my friends. It is true, I was happy enough to find many of them had rambled abroad; but my call will, nevertheless, an∣swer every purpose quite as well.

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Really, Miss Scornwell! this is quite a new method of calculation; it is the first time I have ever heard the absence of friends placed in the chapter of felicities!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: O Madam! we do these things every day—ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Matr.
SP.P: Niece—I had communications for your pri∣vate ear; but as you are at present engaged, and I have visits of friendship to make, I will call on you a few hours hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: I shall expect you with pleasure, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: I suspect, Augusta, that my presence is ill timed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Your presence, my friend, can never be ill timed.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: Thank you, Bloomville. I have had a fatiguing round this morning—the people in this town will never learn breeding—New-York is more than a century advanced before us!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: It is really surprising!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: We are tormented to death by stiff com∣pliments, and all the awkward grimace of ceremony! Heaven hasten the reign of true politeness, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Dear Dorinda, I second your petition with genuine ardour; for I am a perfect enthusiast in my admiration of those easy manners, which are always the appendage of real gentility.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: And then, forsooth! there is an affectation of sentiment, which is altogether intolerable: "I suppose, Miss Scornwell, [speaks affectedly] you was present at the representation of the Jew—Is it not a sweet play?—The Jew was a noble fellow, and Eliza Ratcliff was a most interesting girl—it was replete with sentiment, and both myself and daughters were drown'd in tears."

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: You must own, however, that these re∣marks are not very ill placed.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: Why, to tell you the truth, Bloomville, I am not extravagantly pleased with these same senti∣ments—I prefer cards to conversation, a ride to a book, and the ball-room to the play-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Not a strong predilection in favour of sen∣timent, Miss Scornwell! amazing! Why, sooner than I would confess myself at odds with sentiment, I would relinquish all pretensions to taste, quarrel with benevo∣lence for its benignity, with the sun for its brightness, and with Philenia for the captivating charms of her understanding.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P:
Well, well—I am not desirous of quarrel∣ing with Augusta for any thing. I was last night at
the assembly, where, if I had not expired at the thought of your absence, I should have been the happiest being in the universe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: Yes, indeed; for at the very moment when I was on the point of securing my number, who should enter the ball-room, but the very enamorata that I met at the New-York assemblies; drawn thither, undoubt∣edly, by my irresistible ladyship, and evidently im∣proved in every fascinating grace!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: This was indeed fortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: Fortunate! it threw me into the most happy flow of spirits imaginable.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Did chance give him to you for a partner.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: The Colonel never dances—so we enjoyed a most enchanting aside conversation, cut in at whist, came off victorious in the rubbers, and thus concluded a divine evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Why will you not indulge me with the name of your redoubtable hero?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: Because I mean to present you with the name and person of my Adonis in the same moment; and, by the way, he hath engaged to escort me to your levee this very afternoon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: I shall be happy to see him, undoubtedly. Pray, what figure did our ladies make before this stranger?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: O the frights! but he had eyes only for me. There was Mrs. Gadabout, most preposterously dressed, and Miss Trimwell, loaded with finery, while Betty Brilliant seemed a moving jeweller's shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! O Scornwell! you are mon∣strously severe.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: There, too, was that antiquated dame, Arabella Worthy, whose face is a perfect antidote to every idea of conviviality; not a female but seems to shun her; and yet, because, forsooth! she chooses to com∣mence Argus to her baby-faced daughter, she never misses an assembly! Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Astonishing! Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: Such outree heads—such a redundancy of silks, laces, ribbons and feathers—O it is ridiculous! truly ridiculous, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Dear Dorinda, you have given me as per∣fect an idea of them as if I had myself been present.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: O! by the bye—Do you know that I ab∣solutely saw Tom Dapperwit and Miss Lovett, pass, arm under arm, down the covered promenade last evening? that off down to the ground, eyes rivetted, and tongue as smooth as oil.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Is it possible? I had thought that affair was entirely given up.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss. Sc.
SP.P: O! she is the very quintessence of prude∣ry—But now I think of it, I promised to accompany her this morning, on a visit to Mrs. Arabella Worthy, and I make it a point not to break my word.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Well, dear, Dorinda, I shall expect you at tea, accompanied by your agreeable Colonel. Adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Sc.
SP.P: Adieu. Ma chere amie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: This chere amie of mine, is wholly absorbed in what she terms pleasure—I, too, have made the ex∣periment; I have plunged into a life of gaiety, and the conclusion, which forces itself upon me, does not decide in favour of dissipation. Would, that fate had given me an object in which I could take an interest!—But I must not indulge reflections of this nature—it shall not be long before I will set about a reformation; and, by way of exordium, as I have a few leisure mo∣ments, I will devote them to Miss Clairville.
Request Miss Clairville to favour me with her company.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Yes, an't please your La'ship.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: I have too much neglected the good Eliza of late: There is a kind of dignity and uniform pro∣priety in her deportment, which involves a tacit cen∣sure upon the whim and levity of my more splendid acquaintance.
Miss Clairville, we have, for many weeks, been much estranged; permit me, my dear, to assure you, that this circumstance does not contribute to my felicity.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: You do me honour, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Madam! Why that formal appellation? Let me be known as your Augusta; and address me as in those happy days, when order led the hours, and my aunt presided our sweetly indulgent monitress.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: It was, indeed, a blissful period.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Why that sigh, Eliza? that swelling bo∣som, and that falling tear? Give me leave to tell you, that I have still a heart to feel for the sorrows of my Eliza.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: You are too good, Augusta. My sorrows should be all my own, while happiness remains for Mrs. Bloomville.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Fie! fie! Eliza, do not let despair, with blighting influence, blast your opening prospects. I shall yet see you blest in your own way—the amiable and deserving wife of Maitland.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Never, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Why not? Is he not truly worthy?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: O! he is all luxuriant fancy can image, mid its golden dreams of happiness—In figure, unex∣ceptionable—in grace, inimitable—in mind, the mod∣el of perfection—firm as integrity—melting with sym∣pathy for every child of woe—manly and brave, as conscious worth can render him—mild as the gentle breath of zephyr—candid as mercy—open as the lib∣eral hand of Heaven—and frank as young sincerity.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: O brave! It is evident, however, that his picture is drawn by the lavish pencil of his mistress; but, do you know that this same idol of your's was once on the very point of devoting himself to me; and that your saucy face, very mal-apropos, presented itself to rob me of my conquest? However, be not alarmed, child, I am not vindictive; and I shall give my voice for a speedy wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: I shall never be the wife of Charles Mait∣land, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: What is to hinder, in the name of goodness?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: I will never obtrude myself on a worthy family, which would justly consider me as an obstacle to their advancement.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: We will find means to conciliate the elder Mr. Maitland.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Were he to condescend to woo me for his daughter, I would persist in my rejection.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Strange romantic girl!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Madam, in vindication of this, my unaltera∣ble determination, I will furnish you with some particu∣lars relative to myself, which I have not, till now, thought it necessary to divulge.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: I am all attention.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: I drew my first breath in humble life—my parents commending me to the care of an opulent and noble family in England, left me an infant or∣phan; and my only patrimony was their benediction. From the family in which I was thrown, I received an education which might have suited royalty; but ere I had completed my fifteenth year, my patroness, the first of women, swelled her last sigh! Forgive my tears; the unexampled goodness of my lost benefactress, must ever excite them; they are a tribute due to her inestimable worth!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Your tears are natural, and I cordially sympathize with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P:
My happiness fled with my angel protectress; the family estates devolved on the youngest son, who, of a numerous progeny, alone survived: This gentle∣man was a bachelor, and many years my senior; the ill state of health under which he at that time laboured, with the immoderate grief occasioned by the death of his excellent mother, who had long been his only pa∣rent, induced his physicians to advise a residence of some months in the south of France, and it was judged necessary I should accompany him. What shall I say—a sense of gratitude and honour seems to tie
my tongue, and the shade of my departed benefactress arbitrarily imposes silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Without being a conjurer, I can easily de∣cypher the consequences; your quondam guardian was metamorphosed into a lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: I imagined him a bright exemplar of every virtue; but, forgetful of the ties of honour and the delicacy of my situation, he was capable of forming a deliberate scheme of seduction! and, while he assumed the guise of a tenderness truly paternal, he was cruelly plotting my ruin!!!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: O Lord! I almost gasp for you! By what means did you receive the knowledge of his infamous designs?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: From a faithful friend, who, like a guardian seraph, hovered round my steps, and procured me a sight of letters, written by his own hand, wherein the deep laid scheme was fully arranged!!!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: These, indeed, were indisputable evi∣dences. How did you escape?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: The proofs, as you observe, were irrefragable; and, when he commenced his plan of operation, by inviting me to a little tour, in the progress of which, he engaged to make me certain communications which would importantly involve my future prospects, my vigilant friend received me to her arms, and secretly procured me a rank in the family of that lady, then on the eve of her departure from France, with whom your excellent aunt first saw me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Your history, Eliza, is indeed eventful; but for my soul I cannot see a single circumstance which reason can consider as a bar to your union with Maitland.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Surely, Madam, you must have seen that I am lowly born, portionless and unfriended! and shall I come like a heavy cloud on the prospects of that good young man! a step so reprehensible, would indeed evince me unwarrantably interested; nor will I enter a family whose every attention I should regard as a condescension which would tinge my cheek with the hectic of conscious inferiority.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Do you not perceive, Eliza, that it is hardly consistent with your flighty sentiments, to set such a prodigious value on money?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: I do but submit to a necessity which the despot, Custom, hath rendered irreversible; and besides, Madam, who that hath experienced the luxury of wiping the tear from the haggard cheek of penury, will deny, I had almost said, the omnipotence of money!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. B.
SP.P: Well, well, I will only say that you are a dear, irresistible, romantic girl: But, as the dinner bell rings, we must haste to meet our guests, and we will seize the first opportunity of conversing further on these momentous affairs.

DIV2.HEAD: VIRTUE TRIUMPHANT, continued. ACT THIRD.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE—An Apartment in Mr. Maitland's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: DEAR heart! dear heart! these old eyes are almost blind with weeping! and my grey hairs, I verily think, will be brought with sorrow to the grave!

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Good Robert, be comforted.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Alas! Sir! how can I be comforted? There is no good got by wandering from home. Master Charles, a young man, as you are, can have no idea of the mischiefs which abound in this wicked world!

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: You seem to have forgot those principles which should support your age; you should remember that I shall have the same protection in distant lands that has been my refuge in America.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: This is very true, Sir, but— [sighs deeply.]

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: But what, Robert?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: But these are perilous times, Sir; very perilous times; it looks as if there would not be a mother's son left in the Old World; and, when I con∣sider how often I have carried you in these arms, it afflicts me sorely, Master Charles, that you should run after wars, and murders, and bloodshed.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: I am not going to the field of battle, Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: There is no knowing what may take place, Sir; and then this Colonel Mellfont belongs to the English—every body says they will have bloody times in England, Master Charles; and, for my part, Sir, I think them are best off who have least to do either with French or English.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Fie, fie, Robert, these prejudices are un∣worthy of your benevolence.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Well, may be so, may be so; but my heart strangely misgives me; and if you go, poor Robert will have seen you for the last time! and who is there left to pity or to care for me!!

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: My father will take care of you, Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Ah! Sir, Master is very good; but—but— [weeps.]

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Poor old man! I do not like to see thee weep. Hast thou visited our friends in Stricken Alley, as I requested?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Oh! Sir! could you have heard their piteous lamentations, I am sure it would have melted you!

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Lamentations, Robert?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; for at the same time that I gave them your liberal benefaction, I informed them of your intended departure; and such a general shout of sor∣row, old as I am, I never before heard.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Poor unfortunates!

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: And then such blessings as they poured on you—His reward will be great, said one—It cannot exceed his deservings, said another—May the good God protect him, said all.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: I feel myself enriched by their united ben∣edictions.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: But what, dear Sir, will become of them?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: They shall still be my care.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: But who will take care of Madam Eliza, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: What do you mean, Robert?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Excuse me, Sir, but, in my humble opinion, there never was a more heavenly minded young lady; and I have said it a thousand and a thousand times, that she was the exact resemblance of my young Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; for whenever I have carried her your letters, she has been so gracious, and has inquired so kind after my little orphan grand-children!

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Miss Clairville is indeed an angel.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: And, when I have ventured to speak of your charities, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Of my charities?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; how you took the poor man out of prison; purchased all his goods at auction; and, after restoring both them and him to his wife and children, how you gave him a sum of money to begin business again: How you were constantly taking the part of the oppressed. When I have told her all these things, and much more, Sir, she would turn away to wipe off the tears, and then, lifting up her white hands and beautiful blue eyes to heaven, Robert, says she, your Master is a good young man, and a blessing will surely attend him.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Was my Eliza so kind?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: O yes, Sir, I cannot remember the half of what I have heard her say; but we all think, if once you come together, there will not be a poor person within a hundred miles of your dwelling.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Well, Robert, we must all submit to ne∣cessity. Go, my good fellow, and desire Mr. Weston to step hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: I will go, Sir.—It breaks my heart to think of his turning out into the world in these bad times.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Poor old man! I am not ashamed to own that the parting with him is not the least of my inqui∣etudes. But my Eliza, exalted pattern of every ex∣cellence! may Heaven shield thy virtues: Surely the gifts of fortune are estimated at the very lowest rate, when they are withheld from merit so transcendent, and profusely showered on vice and folly.
Well, Weston, what says my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Weston.
SP.P: He takes the matter precisely as you ex∣pected; he thinks your absence will be temporary; laughs at the idea of your perpetual banishment; and pleases himself with anticipating your victory over a passion which he pronounces extravagant, the mere consequence of youth and inexperience: And he doubts not, he shall see you in the full enjoyment of that happy calm which is the offspring of reason, and the corrected successor of the heyday of the blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: A mere duplicate of what he said to me not an hour since.—I have narrated to you my eclair∣cissement with Miss Clairville.

SP.SPEAKER: Weston.
SP.P: That eclaircissement must have been very satisfactory.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Why, Weston, so it was; and yet, strange as it may seem, while the recollection of her tenderness elevates me above myself, a recurrence to her deter∣mined resolution spreads over my soul a kind of melan∣choly calm, which very much resembles despair.

SP.SPEAKER: Weston.
SP.P: But ought you not rather to implant hope thereon, or at least to forego your design of quitting us?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: To what purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Weston.
SP.P: Methinks flight implies cowardice, while the exercise of manly firmness might restore your peace; and, it should be remembered, that we ought to sustain rather than quit our posts.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: I do not see that my removal from hence is quitting my post.

SP.SPEAKER: Weston.
SP.P: You seem stationed here by Providence; it is your native place, and your munificence has ren∣dered you a general blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: It is not my intention to elude the designs of Providence; I will pursue commerce, and if my father's overgrown fortunes should come into my pos∣session, I will devise a regular system, which shall ren∣der them as useful as their magnitude will admit.

SP.SPEAKER: Weston.
SP.P: Excellent young man! surely the interpo∣sition of Heaven will be manifested in your favour!

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: There is little merit in bestowing on the necessities of others what we cannot possibly appro∣priate to our own emolument. Have you adjusted those accounts which I committed to your care?

SP.SPEAKER: Weston.
SP.P: I have carefully executed your wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Are the receipts past?

SP.SPEAKER: Weston.
SP.P: They are, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Then there remains but one account open; Major Bloomville is considerably in arrears to me, but as I have reason to think his circumstances a little de∣ranged, I will not make application to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Sir, the English Colonel desires to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Show him in, by all means.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: O, lack a day! lack a day!

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: The deep grief, of which this fellow's countenance is expressive, really affects me.

SP.SPEAKER: Weston.
SP.P: It must indeed interest your humanity; but I will now devote myself to those preparations which yet remain to be made previous to your departure.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Do, Mr. Weston.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: Mr. Maitland, your most obedient—I have called on you to learn if you held your pur∣pose, relative to your journey; but I could hardly per∣suade your servant to permit my entrance.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P:
He is a weak old man; and, much con∣cerned at the prospect of my departure, he has, perhaps,
conceived a kind of prejudice against the person, to whom he imputes a design, which he imagines so ill advised. There is some allowance due to years, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: Undoubtedly. Poor fellow, I would glad∣ly dry his tears—I always feel compassion for persons in a state of servitude and dependence, Mr. Maitland.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: You are perfectly right, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: Your servant, Mr. Maitland, has an added claim to my attention; old age, and grief, are power∣ful recommendations to that heart, which hath been long a proficient in the school of affliction.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: I have often been fearful that your bosom harboured some latent cause of grief; and our last con∣versation, without explaining the nature of your mis∣fortunes, has confirmed my suspicions, given me a very important interest in your happiness, and originated a wish that I could be any how instrumental in produc∣ing it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: You are truly friendly; but, as the knowl∣edge of my misfortunes can be of no immediate im∣port, it may suffice to say that I am unhappy; that I wander from place to place without diminishing my sorrow, and that I hardly expect a remedy this side the grave.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Pardon me, Sir; I can commiserate, with∣out being impertinent.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: Nay, the probability is, that the accusa∣tion of impertinence will devolve upon me; for, I am induced to put a question, which only a long and ap∣proved friendship can justify. I am informed, that you quit this town with a declaration that you will never return to it again! and that you are driven hence by unsuccessful love! Can this be true?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: It is, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: Methinks, Mr. Maitland, the lady must have made an erroneous calculation, who refuses to ex∣change her vows with your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P:
You are very polite, Sir; but mine is no uncommon case. Fortune, blind to the perfections of
the most charming and accomplished of women, sat her down in her book of distributions, pennyless.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: Does your father approve of your attach∣ment?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: By no means; he condemns it as the gross∣est absurdity.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: But how happens it that he has no eyes for merit so conspicuous?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: My father has never yet seen Miss Clair∣ville. An excess of delicacy leading her to conceive that visiting in promiscuous company, and frequent∣ing public places, would ill accord with her humble fortune—she is only to be met in the circle of a few in∣timate friends, with whom my father is not conversant.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: This is unfortunate—if you could, by any means, procure an interview, youth, beauty and innocence might become very powerful pleaders.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Alas! Sir, my father will not see my Eli∣za; and, if he could even be brought to consent to our union, it is more than probable Miss Clairville would reject our united supplications; for, while she has, in the most unequivocal terms, avowed her preference, she has, with the same breath, declared that she will never meet me at the altar, but on equal ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: This is noble, it must be confessed; but it is easier to form resolutions than to persist in them; in∣deed, the capability of such a determination, is, in it∣self, a prodigious effort, especially in a young woman. She, doubtless, has her advisers—are any of her friends within my knowledge?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: I think you mixed in the same circles with Miss Dorinda Scornwell, while in New-York; her in∣timacy with the Bloomville family, gives her frequent opportunities with my Eliza.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: This may be a happy circumstance. I will request the honour of her private ear. I have of∣ten known female influence acquire an ascendency, which demanded the utmost address to surmount.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Ah! Sir, you are about to engage in a very untoward affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: Perhaps not. I have some knowledge of the character of your father—if I could converse with him on your subject, I have a pre-sentiment that I could inspire him with a degree of complacency for my opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: You would find it an Herculean labour; but I will step to the library, where, at this hour, he is commonly to be found, and I dare say he will be with you in a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: Written in the irreversible decrees of fate, the son of sorrow! I would extract a balm for my lac∣erated bosom from every fair occasion, in the which I can mitigate the ills, that seem allotted for a fellow creature: Indeed, the power to soothe the woe-fraught mind, partakes essentially the nature of divinity. O Howard! Howard! illustrious philanthropist! thou wert the veriest mental epicure that ever mere humanity embodied.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Give me leave, Sir, to introduce to you my very worthy friend, Col. Mellfont.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Servant, Sir—servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: I am, Sir, happy in an opportunity of paying my respects to the parent of a young person, to whom my heart hath, for a considerable time, been not a little attached.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: I am obliged to you, Sir; but, as to happi∣ness, Sir, it is an extreme which may do well enough as a Utopian plant, but which has never yet been found to take a very deep root in America.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: We accustom ourselves, Sir, to a language, which, although perhaps, strictly speaking, is not chaste; yet, as it is generally understood, receives, nev∣ertheless, a current acceptation.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Ah, very likely, very likely—this world is given to see things through a false medium.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P:
I am perfectly of your opinion, Sir; the world is, indeed, given to error; it is only a select few who see things as they are; while the blinded multitude,
borne in the vortex of folly, will continue their idle whirl on the very brink of destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: That is a striking sentiment, Sir—"the blinded multitude, borne in the vortex of folly, will continue their idle whirl upon the very brink of destruction." I congrat∣ulate thee, Charles, on having attained so valuable a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Sir, I have long been deeply impressed with a very high sense of the worth of Col. Mellfont.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: You are very obliging, gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Sir, you deserve it; you have spoken ration∣ally. I have always been a cool, deliberate man, Sir, a lover of reason, and a friend of equality: Some of my countrymen hate Frenchmen—some hate Englishmen—these are both extremes, Sir; but, for my part, I love a man of worth, let him be the growth of what clime he will. I am a true brother of the Roy∣al Arch—my motto is equality, and I embrace the brotherhood with my whole heart, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: Admirable, Mr. Maitland—truly admira∣ble! I have often wondered at the early virtues of my friend Charles; but, as his youth has been formed under the genial influence of an example so transcend∣ently excellent, I shall henceforward cease to wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Why, ah! Charles is well enough for a young man, as young men go—he has, perhaps, a few youthful follies that stand in need of pruning, and he may make a tolerable figure.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: I cannot but regret, Sir, whatever pleas∣ure I may anticipate from the tour, that he is so soon to be removed from your guardian observation.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: It is his own choice, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: Perhaps, Sir, this choice may be influenced by circumstances. I suppose, my friend, that you would prefer a father's wing, to a state of wandering, amid that world of which you, at present, know so little?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Certainly, Sir; but, such is my unhappy situation, that those scenes which have heretofore con∣tributed to my felicity, now stand forth, mementos of the severity of my destiny!

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Ah! let him make the experiment, Colo∣nel—let him make the experiment—he talks of never returning; but, this is all mere romance: we shall soon see him again, like the prodigal son, cap in hand; and he will then know how to distinguish prop∣erly, and to make prudent calculations, Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Sir, you are my father; I therefore owe you reverence, and I will be patient.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Patience! ah, there is not a better ingredi∣ent in life, Charles, than patience; it is the very es∣sence of Moderation—cultivate patience, boy, and thou shalt have my blessing with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: Spoken like a father! I dare say, Sir, it is your wish that your son should prosecute business under your own eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; but, if he, not having received a sufficient quantum of centripetal force, is thus neglect∣ful of the laws of gravitation, thus centrifugally in∣clined, and chooses to fly off in a tangent, I shall not consti∣tute his antipodes—I shall not weep myself into a Niobe; I can tell him that, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: Will you permit me, Sir, as the friend of your son, and the admirer of yourself, to speak with freedom?

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: O Sir, I have all suitable regard to free∣dom; and it is my wish to support liberty of speech, by all means.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: In perfect confidence then, that I shall not offend, and with all due deference to your superior judgment, I will say, that I do not know any event that can have a more probable tendency to establish a young man in life, with the fairest prospects of tranquil∣ity, than an early connexion with a discreet and de∣serving young woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, provided always, that the choice of the said young woman be discreetly made, Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: And what, Sir, in your opinion, constitutes a discreet choice?

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P:
Equality, Sir; by all means, equality. If I have got ten thousand pound, the case is clear, she
must lay down ten thousand pound; and thus it will appear a connexion of cool, deliberate prudence, and not the impassioned, high flying result of romantic folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: But, Sir, are there not qualities infinitely more valuable than riches?

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Undoubtedly, Sir; and if it were a law as irrevocable as that of the Medes and Persians, that no one, who possessed money, should superadd merit, I would assuredly give my voice in favour of merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: You would, certainly, Mr. Maitland, find an exquisite pleasure in transplanting virtue into the most friendly soil.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Give me leave to tell you, Colonel, once for all, that I am not fond of your exquisites—moderation is my desideratum; and my plan is, to abide by its dictates.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: Moderation is certainly highly estimable, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Why, now, Col. Mellfont, in things of less consequence, you would be in the exercise of prudence—you would not stake a thousand pound, in a game of whist or quadrille, against six-pence, Colonel. My name is Ralph Maitland, Sir; and I am determined to act for myself—I have not yet got into my dotage, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: You ought, undoubtedly, Sir, to be your own master; and you are right, in supposing I would not hazard a thousand pound against six-pence; and yet, Sir, I should conceive, that a thousand pound was well laid out, in purchasing a virtue, in communicating felicity, or, in placing a fellow-creature in the rank, for which nature seems to have designed her.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P:
Ah! ah! all this is very fine talking; but virtue is not to be bought and sold, nor, do I pretend to write notes, critical and explanatory, on the designs of nature; and, moreover, Colonel, you are quite wide in your calculations, for I am not ignorant of the pur∣pose for which you have given yourself all this unnec∣essary trouble; but, I say, you are quite wide of the
matter; it is not in my power to communicate felicity, for the young woman, being a rational young wom∣an, is herself perfectly convinced, that her connexion with my son would, in the nature of things, be highly preposterous.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: This conviction must have proceeded from a sweet and amiable disposition; it has made me a lover of her character; did she assure you of this her∣self, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: O, no Sir, I never saw her in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: And do you not think it would be proper you should pay her a visit of acknowledgment on this occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Perhaps it may, Sir; and in order to con∣vince Charles that I will comply with him in all that is reasonable, I do not much care if I call upon the girl on this business.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Did you call, master Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: No, good Robert; and I would thank you to see that we are not broken in upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: I will, Sir, I will. Heaven bless him; I have not seen him look so happy this many a day; who knows what may happen after all! [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: We shall be subject to continual interrup∣tions here, Charles, I will therefore invite you both to my library, and we will there adjust the necessary pre∣liminaries to this visit of acknowledgment.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. M.
SP.P: I will attend you with pleasure, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Sir, you have bound me to you by yet added ties.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE—The Vestibule of Mr. Maitland's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: Here you, Mr. Grey Hairs, where is my friend Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: My master, Sir, is very busy, and can't be interrupted at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: Can't be interrupted, rascal?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Rascal, Sir! that is a name which I never yet received from either of my masters!

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: Don't prate, old fellow, don't prate, I say; or, as I am a soldier, I will lend thee a blow that shall lay thee as stiff as was Julius Cesar, when he was beheaded by Oliver Cromwell. Sir, I am your master's friend; tell him Captain Flashet waits for him, and you will see he will present himself imme∣diately, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Bless me! what a fiery blade it is; I had best decamp, I believe!

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: If we men of the sword do not exert our∣selves, and be seen in our places, we shall be treated with as little respect as a dead Carthagenian, and as our employment is undoubtedly honourable, even as hon∣ourable as was that of the great Charles of Constantinople, when he swore eternal enmity to the Russian Scipio's, so I think proper to behave with dignity, and to show, on all occasions, a becoming spirit.
Send that grey headed old fellow to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: Why Tantalus, when he was broil'd on the gridiron by old Father Gregory, was never worse treated.
Well sirrah, where is your master—ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Good Sir, be not angry with an old man! My master Sir, bid me to make his excuses, and tell you that being engaged in business of importance, he could not wait on you at this time.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: You lie, sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Indeed Sir, I—

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, you old scoundrel—I'll teach you what it is to affront an officer of my rank.
SP.STAGE: [Collars and shakes him furiously—Robert roars out.]

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: For shame, for shame, Captain! lift your hand against a feeble, grey headed old man!

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: Yes Sir, an old scoundrel who has used me ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Sir, he is not a scoundrel; he has acted en∣tirely by my direction.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: Acted by your direction, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Yes Sir, and what have you to say to that, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: That I am not treated like a gentleman, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Robert, you may go.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Now pray, dear master—

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Away—you know I will be obeyed. [Ex∣it Robert, agitated and alarmed.] If you conceive your∣self injured, Captain Flashet, I will not deny you re∣dress. I do not mean to violate the laws of hospitali∣ty in this mansion; but you will know how to call on me, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. F.
SP.P: O! not in the least, my dear friend, not in the least! no, I perfectly coincide in opinion with the brave Tacitus, in his reply to Pope Clement—If Clem∣ent is tired of his life, he shall not find death on the point of my sword: So, my very dear friend, I wish you a ve∣ry good day.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha—this is truly ridiculous—ha, ha, ha.

DIV2.HEAD: VIRTUE TRIUMPHANT, continued. ACT FOURTH.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE—An Apartment in Major Bloomville's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P:
HEIGH ho! Time wears but slowly; and yet, when I think on to-morrow's sun, it hath an eagle's wing! Farewel! a last farewel!
What deep-felt pangs doth that heart-affecting word involve!!!

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: Miss Eliza, there is a gentleman, Mr. Mait∣land, who wishes to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Hah! I had thought his visit would have been delayed until evening. [Aside.] Be so good as to desire Mr. Maitland to walk in.

And now, assist me, each incentive which can ren∣der firm a feeble maiden—shed over me thy invigorat∣ing influence, divine fortitude—support me through this last interview! and to tender regret, a comfort∣less victim, I thenceforward devote me!

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: An assemblage of all that is lovely in wo∣man! [Aside.] I hope I do not intrude, young lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: In the name of wretchedness, who can this be? [Aside.] Have you any commands for me, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: For thee, Madam! Thou lookest as if thou wert formed to give, rather than receive commands! O the rogues! they knew what a trial they were pre∣paring for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Perhaps, Sir, you wish to see Major Bloom∣ville, or his lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: No, sweet lady; if thou art Miss Clairville, my business is with thee: Canst thou lend me thine ear for half an hour?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Will you have the goodness to let me know from whom I receive a request so uncommon?

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: And is there no one striking lineament, by which thou canst recognize the father, from his resem∣blance to the son?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Hah! Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: It were a sin, young lady, to keep thee in a moment's painful suspense: My name is Ralph Mait∣land, Miss Clairville, and I am very much at thy service, I assure thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Amazement!

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, I am the father of a head∣strong boy, who has given thee much uneasiness; and I have to thank thee for the exercise of a degree of moderation, which is very seldom found among the catalogue of a woman's virtues.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Can I believe my ears?

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Give them full credit, my dear; thou shalt hear nothing but truth from Ralph Maitland.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: This is a very un∣expected visit, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Be composed, Miss Eliza: We have, per∣haps, hitherto been a mutual terror to each other; but henceforward I request thee to know me for thy friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: My friend, Sir! O how soothing is that tender appellation! how balmy to the wounded bo∣som of the orphan Eliza!

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: And hast thou been so deeply wounded, Eliza?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, you see before you the daugh∣ter of misfortune and of sufferance; alas! I know no other parents.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Young lady, I advise thee to take comfort; I confess obligations to thee; and I assure thee, that I would willingly go almost any lengths to serve thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Your countenance, Sir, is a pleasing index of the goodness of your mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Be assured, Miss Clairville, that I lament every circumstance that opposes my styling myself thy father.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Alas! Sir, to hail the venerable name of Father, was not reserved for the poor Eliza; my in∣fant tongue was never taught to lisp it; and in no moment has my maturer years, with unauthorized presumption, aspired to so vast an acquisition.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Interesting woman! henceforward I acquit my son!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Alas! Sir, I should reckon your censure of that good young man as a serious calamity.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Then he shall not have my censure, Mad∣am; for I will never contribute to thy inquietude.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: You are unexpectedly kind, Sir; but for me, accustomed to misfortunes, I have learned to bear them; my life has been a life of humiliation, and my most arduous struggles to submit to that necessity which destiny hath imposed.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: By my serenity, a fascinating girl!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Yet I have had friends, Sir; with gratitude I make this confession; and the privilege of ranking Mr. Maitland in the number, is a circumstance which furnishes a relief, that is, on the present occasion, truly necessary.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: If I have ever, Miss Clairville, given thee a moment's pain, I repent it from my soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: And I, Sir, take leave to make the same ac∣knowledgment: An interference with your plans has ever been foreign from my intention.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: I doubt it not, Madam. Wilt thou permit one question? Has my son's departure thy appro∣bation?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Perhaps, Sir, I have no right to give an opinion respecting his movements.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Yes, Madam; friendship alone will author∣ize thee; and, as I respect thy judgment, I take the liberty to solicit thy sentiments on a step so important as his contemplated tour.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: You do me too much honour, Sir; but, as I feel a degree of confidence in your indulgence, I will say, that I think young men of observation cannot fail of reaping advantage from a knowledge of the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Unexampled prudence! But perhaps, Miss Eliza, thou dost not love, or, as young ladies phrase it, thou hast no preference for my son?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Hah! Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Canst thou, Miss Clairville, rise so far su∣perior to the forms and fashions of thy sex, as to tell me plainly, how thy heart stands in regard to my son?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Circumstanced as I am, Sir, your question, it must be owned, is a little singular.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: It is so, Madam; but my freedom is a proof of my esteem.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: To be distinguished by you, Sir, must un∣questionably be highly gratifying to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Consider me as an old man, and do not hesitate.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: I have ever reverenced years, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Do not evade my question, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: I will not make a merit with you, Sir, for an avowal which will be entitled to no praise. From the first dawn of my reason, I have been accustomed to admire virtue, even to a degree of enthusiasm; and I have been taught to feel a strong predilection in fa∣vour of every genteel and graceful accomplishment.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Well, Miss Clairville.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: And I do not wish to conceal, that I have not felt my attachment to the virtues and the graces diminish, because they happen to be personified by Charles Maitland.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: And this ingenuous declaration thou dost not wish to conceal?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: No, Sir; for, not choosing to present myself as a candidate for matrimonial life, I care not who knows, that I have no heart to give.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: But it is very natural for a young woman to contemplate an establishment by wedlock.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Undoubtedly, Sir; but, as I believe there are joys and sorrows peculiar to every situation in life, and, as I have conceived that it is not so much the part, as the acting well that part, which entitles the per∣former to respectability, so I am determined to rest satis∣fied with that character in the Drama, in which the great Manager seems to have cast me my lot.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Admirable young woman!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Your approbation, Sir, is truly soothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Thou hast thought very deeply, Madam, and made uncommon proficiency.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Adversity, Sir, is an excellent school.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.STAGE: [Walks about irresolute, and appears much moved, after which he says:]
SP.P:
I have conceived, Miss Clairville, that there was a natural beauty in proprie∣ty, an unalterable rule of right, and an eternal fitness of
things; nor will I yet relinquish my principles. Op∣position to thee, enchanting maid, must constitute the extreme of obstinacy; while, in thy lovely bosom, every virtue hath found a calm and happy asylum.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Alas! Sir; you little know the imbecility of that heart which you would thus exalt.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Thou shalt weep no more, my love—Know me henceforth as thy protecting father—the wishes of my son have now the fullest sanction.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Amazement!

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Wilt thou not accept me as thy paternal friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: On my knees, Sir, I supplicate eternal sunshine on that dear paternal bosom—but know, Sir, that my sacred, my irrevocable vow is registered in heaven—I can never wear the envied title of your daughter, except a miracle should render me the equal of your son; nor can even the wishes of Mr. Maitland recal the solemn hour which witnessed a transaction, that renders his unexampled condescension forever in∣effectual.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Astonishing! What hast thou done, Eliza?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Forgive me, Sir; but, fearing that my ten∣derness would one day betray my resolution, I bound myself by ties indissoluble.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: My persevering obstinacy has undone my son! Rise, Eliza, dear, rash, heroic, and uncommon girl! What step remaineth to be taken?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: To submit to destiny, Mr. Mait∣land; and remember that this life is but a passage to a better scene of things.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: It is a hard necessity.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: You accuse me of rashness, Sir: You be∣hold in me an orphan, friendless, poor, and claiming no natural protector! nor did I ever yet behold the being, whom I could challenge as relation! Consider, Sir, is such a female a fit companion for your son? Subordination, rank and degree, are of divine origin∣al; the lines are justly drawn; and he who breaks the rank assigned him by his Creator, is surely an aggressor.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Dear, uncommon girl! never were my own sentiments so well expressed before—it were a crime of no inferior dye, to urge thee further—I cannot even wish thee to relinquish ideas, originating in divine propriety. But what, Miss Clairville, are thy plans? Wilt thou permit me to regard thee as the daughter of my affection?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: My utmost gratitude is due to Mr. Mait∣land—But, although orphanaged with my first breath, I have received from strangers that kind of education which secures my independence.

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: High-soul'd girl! it is impossible to fasten on thee the shadow of an obligation! Dost thou ex∣pect to see my son before his departure?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: I do, Sir: As if in love with anguish, we have appointed this evening to exchange the last farewel!

SP.SPEAKER: Maitl.
SP.P: Charming frankness! Admirable young la∣dy! I tear myself from thee.
